sourceDesc.p: Generated from the Filemaker export of 2016-07-29.

note.p: Criteria for this are occurence in comparative constructions, cooccurrence with words like 甚，最，太／大，極 .

div.head: object=plant
div.p: the object refers to a plant

div.head: object=goal
div.p: the object is the goal of an actions

div.head: inch
div.p: inchoative, referring to a first step in any new development or complex action which may or may not be performed successfully.
Contrast "ingressive" which refers to the initial part of a completed change of state.
conative: tried to become a professor
inchoative: was in the process of becoming a professor

div.head: request
div.p: (sentence final expressing a) request or mild imperative

div.head: reflexive.self-referential-汝
div.p: Self-reference in the object, with a second person pronoun 汝 .

div.head: change
div.p: change: referring to the passing from one state to another, with a clear focus on both.

note.p: Change words which focus not on the two states but on the second of the states only are as follows:
conative: tried to become a professor
inchoative: was in the process of becoming a professor

bibl.title: Encyclopedia of Language and Linguistics. Second Edition

div.head: object=fact
div.p: the object refers to a fact

div.head: N=period of time
div.p: the noun refers to a period of time

div.head: object=quotation
div.p: the object refers to a quotation

div.head: object=crime
div.p: the object refers to a crime

div.head: derived
div.p: derived or extended, but not obviously figurative meaning

div.head: N1 compared to subject of VtoN2
apodosis
div.p: (final particle, etc.) indicating the apodosis in a conditional sentence

div.head: object=problem
div.p: the object of the verb is a problem

div.head: N1 and N2 non-homogeneous
div.p: N1 and N2 not of the same type.

div.head: V1 the same way as V2
object=feature
div.p: the object refers to a feature

div.head: reflexive.自.ownN
div.p: a reflexive in which the object is the subject's "own", with 自

div.head: passive
div.p: passivized; used in a passive sense

note.p: passive usage is not limited to verbs: English "destruction" is often used as a passive abstract noun "the destruction of Carthage by the Romans", and moreover, passive use is surprisingly often linked with an omission of a lexically determinate logical subject: 不可殺 "must not be killed" has "by anyone" as a lexically determinate subject, and should probably be vt[0]oN - pass. These matters need further reflection and have not so far been formalised in the TLS system.

div.head: litotes
div.p: semantically involving the rhetorical device of litotes (See RHETORICAL DEVICES: litotes)

div.head: method
div.p: (abstract noun) designating a method of doing things.

div.head: object=culprit
div.p: the object refers to the culprit

note.p: See Harbsmeier, The Syntax of classical Chinese Numerals.

div.head: reflexive.自.ownname
div.p: reflexive in 自 , referring to the use of the subject's own name
NB: This is messy, but we need to be reminded somehow that this kind of reflexivity exists. It is ubiquitous in SHANHAIJING.

div.head: V=factive
div.p: See Paul Kiparski's brilliant article on factive verbs. // Should we put this kind of info here?

div.head: tr
div.p: The semantic feature tr is attributed when a verb (or occasionally a noun) has a semantic structure that essentially involves reference to an object although according to the principles of the syntactic description it is classified as intransitive.
NB: The implementation of this semantic category has still not been tried out in any detail and presents all sorts of problems.

div.head: reflexive
div.p: Noun or verb involving reflexive semantics of various kinds. [Preliminary unhomogeneous set of examples.]

note.p: We use this feature when under a given synonym group two meanings differ mainly by the addition of the feature semantic feature "causative". This raises a host of theoretical and descriptive problems.

The causatives raise systematic problems: should one enter "teach" as a causative of "learn". Logically yes, linguistically also. But pragmatically, in the context of traditional lexicography, this would become quite confusing.
Permission needs separate treatment, but has not yet got it

div.head: act
div.p: This category covers both finite actions and "on-going" activities. The criterion determining whether something is an actiivty or not is whether it is construed as involving the agent's intentions or not. Thus "falling" is not normally an activity, but sky-diving is.

The subcategorisation of actions into durative, conative, perfective, iterative, inchoative, ingressive etc., etc. has not been attempted in any systematic way so far, largely because in the end it will involve a considerable effort of dividing a given lexeme entry into various lexeme entries specified for their durative, conative semantic features.

div.head: nonreferential
div.p: non-referential. This category includes a wide variety of usages of nouns which in subject or in object position do not serve to identify any definite item or set of items in the world.

note.p: Many of these, like 王者 , have no referential uses, others, like the pronoun 之 , have striking common lexicalised non-referential meanings, but are even more common in referential meanings.
It is clear that the general category nonref needs to be subcategorised because it is too comprehensive as it stands.

bibl.title: Encyclopedia of Language and Linguistics. Second Edition

div.head: resultative
div.p: Resultative are those verbs and action nouns which refer to the result (and not only the conclusion ) of an action or a process.
The distinction between RESULTATIVE and PERF is not always clear, nor is it consistently applied so far.

div.head: reference=unspecified
div.p: the reference (of for example a pronoun) is unspecified

div.head: om
div.p: This belongs to an early stage of the database, is redundant in some cases, and where it is not redundant one must change vt - om to vt(+N).

div.head: social
div.p: abstract noun with social reference, in the most general sense.

div.head: N=abstract
div.p: N is an abstract nominal expression

div.head: meta
div.p: metaphysical is the very broadest sense of the term.

div.head: object=event
div.p: the object refers to an event

div.head: imp
div.p: Imperative use of a verb. These uses of a verb badly need to be studied, particularly because they tend to be grammatically unmarked in Chinese.

bibl.title: Encyclopedia of Language and Linguistics. Second Edition

div.head: object=beneficiary
div.p: the object is the beneficiary of an action

div.head: med
div.p: middle voice, neither active nor passive, but in between

note.p: This remains a problematic category the need for which was discovered late. A large number of verbs with the category pass need to be moved here, if one wants to remain serious about this category.

div.head: plur
div.p: A distinction needs to be made between a lexeme that CAN be used in the plural (plur), and a lexeme entry that MUST have plural reference (plur!). This has not yet been implemented.

div.head: object=food
div.p: the object refers to an edible item

div.head: reference=ruler
div.p: the reference is to the ruler

div.head: object=document
div.p: the object refers to a document

div.head: putative.reflex.自
div.p: reflexives which involve a putative component, i.e. the meaning that a semantic component is thought to be present, with 自

div.head: reduplicated.AABB
div.p: reduplicated disyllabic word occurring in the pattern AABB

div.head: desired result
div.p: (sentence final, suffix) indicating a desired result (indicated by the V)

div.head: "be being"
div.p: Hier bin ich Mensch, hier darf ich's sein

div.head: not ours
div.p: not pertaining or relating to the speaker

div.head: N=hum; non-referential
div.p: the reference being to a human N, and the N not referring to any specific person

div.head: factive
div.p: Verbs like KNOW which presuppose the truth of the sentence or proposition that is their object.

div.head: NPab nominalised with 之or 其
SUBJ=autonymous
div.p: The subject is a character that refers to itself, i.e. is autonymous in Bertrand Russell's sense.

div.head: SUBJ of V1 = SUBJ of V2
N2 in the service of N1
N1 SUBJECT not agent of feature N2
ACT:N1=subject of the V in NP{nominalised by 所}
N1 SUBJECT (not agent!) of feature N2
MODIFY:N=denominal adverb modifying the V in NP{所V}
N compared with respect to VP-ing
N compared to SUBJ of S
N1 compared to the object N2
object N1 contrasted with object N2
object N1 compared with object N2
N1 compared to subject of N2
TIME MODIFY:N1=time when event N2 occurred
SUBJECT (not agent!) N1 subjectof feature N2
MODIFATION:N=denominal adverb modifying the V in NP{所V}
SUBJECT:N1=subject of the V in NP{nominalised by 所}
ADVERB:N=denominal adverb modifying the V in NP{所V}
COMPARISON.be as V as an N
TIME MODIFY:N1=time to which N2 belongs
postnominal instrumental, N and N coreferential
SUBJECT (not agent!) N1 subject of feature N2
N2 serving the purposes of N1
nominalisation with 之 or 其
NPab=an S nominalised by 之/其
